summary: The document provides a historical account of Charles J. SEITZ, detailing his career as a test pilot and former U.S. Army flight mechanic, including his service in Vietnam and Thailand. It highlights his consideration for a role in Project WUBETON under the Department of Defense (DOD) and his employment at the FLOURNOY Flying Service alongside Leslie Norman BRADLEY. The document also notes BRADLEY's reaction to President John F. Kennedy's assassination and includes personal details about SEITZ and his father, Charles William SEITZ, such as their employment history and residences.
key_findings: Charles J. SEITZ was a test pilot and former U.S. Army flight mechanic with tours in Vietnam and Thailand.
SEITZ was being considered for a role in Project WUBETON by the DOD.
Both SEITZ and his father were employed by the FLOURNOY Flying Service, which went out of business in 1964.
Leslie Norman BRADLEY, a colleague of SEITZ at FLOURNOY, reportedly wanted to go to Miami immediately after President Kennedy's assassination.
